tossups.question: According to Business Insider, a school of management building designed by this man was designated the 2nd ugliest building in Ohio, behind the Longaberger basket. This former Los Angeles truck driver tried both chemical engineering and radio announcing before settling on architecture. A design by this man that depicts the plains of Kansas was chosen for the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial in D.C. This man was sued after a water leakage occurred in his (*) Stata Center at MIT. He created a building which evokes imagery of two moving people called Dancing House. For 10 points, name this Canadian-born architect famous for his Experience Music Project in Seattle, Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles, and Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao.

The author of this novel was unsure whether or not to complete it after the death of her partner’s son. This novel’s setting precedes the 1832 Reform Act, and its prelude claims that while St. Theresa led a life of greatness, many others who are just as good will never have the chance to achieve fame. In this novel, Mary Garth refuses to help the dying Peter Featherstone. The death of Sir John Raffles in this novel was in part due to banker (*) Nicholas Bulstrode. One of the main plots of this novel focuses on Dr. Lydgate, while another encompasses Mr. Casaubon’s efforts to alter his will in order to prevent Will Ladislaw from marrying Casaubon’s widow. For 10 points, name this George Eliot novel about Dorothea Brooke set in the title town, subtitled “A Study in Provincial Life.”
tossups.answer: Middlemarch: A Study of Provincial Life <Kumar>

tossups.question: A woman at the bottom middle of a painting with this title washes a baby’s bottom next to a fire roasting a boar’s head. To the right of that fire, a doctor checks a patient’s teeth beneath a diagram of vermin invading a heart. Another painting of this name was originally titled Landscape: Noon and includes a (*) white-and-brown dog looking at two men heading towards a woman reaching into a river. That painting of this name features smoke rising from the chimney of Willy Lott’s Cottage, and the former painting with this name features three panels depicting fallen angels, Hell, and the title mode of transportation in the center. For 10 points, give this name of a triptych by Bosch and a rural painting about a farm cart in a river by John Constable.
tossups.answer: The Hay Wain [or The Haywain Triptych] <McMaken>

tossups.question: One of these places holds the head of a shapeshifting ogre and is only visible on certain days of the year. Another one of these places has its main hall always lit and includes red, wooden structures built to represent people’s donations. Births and deaths are prohibited near these structures, so pregnant and ill people are required to (*) take a boat back to the mainland to avoid impurities. Small, street-side examples of these were called hokora. In these places, visitors must perform a ritual ablution using a temizuya, and only then can they walk into the main complex. Ema are wooden plaques at these places, and omamori are amulets sold at these locations. For 10 points, name these non-Buddhist Japanese places of worship, famous for their Torii gates.
tossups.answer: Shinto shrines [or jinja; do not accept Shinto temples] <Yoshida>

tossups.question: This man was part of a group dubbed the “Great Triumvirate” or “Immortal Trio” and helped to negotiate the treaty of Ghent ending the War of 1812, of which he was also a proponent. His first term in the House of Representatives, from 1811 to 1813, was also his first term as Speaker of the House. This man was viewed as the primary representative for Western interests during the (*) Missouri Compromise, the Compromise Tariff of 1833, and the Compromise of 1850, and he was nicknamed “Harry of the West” and “The Western Star.” This man ran for president thrice, in 1824, 1832, and finally in 1844, losing all three times. For 10 points, name this American Statesman who developed the American System and become known as “The Great Compromiser.”

Jupiter Hammon once wrote an ode to this person, whose first poem was about the University of Cambridge. In one work, this person wrote about “when Gallic powers Columbia’s fury found” and, for a certain figure, wished “thy ev’ry action let the Goddess decide / A crown, a mansion, and a throne that shine.” This poet wrote many elegies, the most famous of which was for (*) George Whitefield. This poet said “Remember, Christians, Negroes, black as Cain, / May be refin'd, and join th' angelic train,” in a poem included in her collection Poems on Various Subjects, Religious and Moral. For 10 points, name this American poet of works such as “To His Excellency, George Washington,” and “On Being Brought From Africa to America.”

When this man was captured by pirates and sold as a slave, according to both Menippus and Eubulus he said that the one thing he was good at was "ruling men" and proceeded to point to his buyer, whom he said needed a master. This philosopher refuted a paradox of Eubulides that people had horns by touching people on the forehead, and he refuted Plato’s claim that (*) man is a “featherless biped” by plucking a chicken and saying, “Behold! I’ve brought you a man!” This philosopher told Alexander the Great to “get out of my sunlight,” and he lived in a tub while carrying a lantern around in broad daylight searching for “one honest man.” For 10 points, name this Greek philosopher who acted like a dog and founded Cynicism.

Citing asthma, this man resigned as head of his political party in 1985, passing leadership onto his hand-picked successor Son Sen. Born Saloth Sar, this man, widely known by his nom de guerre, implemented the Year Zero project in 1976, which involved the mass evacuation of citizens from large urban centers. Assuming the title (*) “brother number one” upon his assumption of power in 1975, this man, with his political party widely known as “Angkar,” sought to form a socialist agrarian utopia. Up to one million people were executed in “killing fields” under the direction of, for 10 points, what Cambodian communist leader, whose followers were known as the Khmer Rouge?
tossups.answer: Pol Pot [accept Saloth Sar before mentioned] <Halza>

tossups.question: In one prophecy of this figure, it is foreseen that though he abandoned his people, he will return to bring on a new age of prosperity. This figure’s chariot is pulled by four horses which have poison in their mouths, and he gives the dragon Mushussu to his son (*) Nabu. This god’s name is usually preceded by the word for “lord,” and his name means “solar calf.” This four-eyed and four-eared god prepared for a battle by throwing lightning before himself and filling his body with fire. He then used a net, deadly winds, and an arrow to pierce the belly of his foe, the primordial sea dragon Tiamat. He then went on to take the Tablets of Destiny from Kingu. For 10 points, name this god of the Near East, the lord of lords.
tossups.answer: Bel Marduk [accept Bel, Bel Belum, Bel Rabim. Check a list of his 50 names if they provide an unlisted answer and protest] <Yoshida>

tossups.question: A scientist with this last name won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1930 for his research on chlorophyll and his synthesis of the iron-containing porphyrin hemin. Another scientist with this last name invented a namesake synthesis with Hans Tropsch that turns gases into liquid hydrocarbons, and yet another scientist with this name was responsible for the first synthesis of (*) caffeine. That scientist with this last name discovered a namesake reaction involving the refluxing of carboxylic acid and an alcohol to form an ester, and he also gives his name to the symbolic way to draw asymmetric carbon atoms. For 10 points, give the last name of the 1902 recipient of the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, who names an esterification and a projection.

Douglas Erwin’s “Murder on the Orient Express Hypothesis” attempts to provide a multi-component analysis to explain the largest of these events. Cyanobacteria were responsible for one of the most significant of these events that impacted obligate anaerobic organisms. Glaciation and (*) gamma ray bursts are hypothesized to be the main causes of the first major one of these events, and a more recent example helped mammals and birds to dominate on land. A sixth major type of these events dubbed the “Anthropocene” one impacted passenger pigeons and dodo birds and is ongoing today. For 10 points, name these events such as the K-T and the Permian “Great Dying,” which can be caused by asteroid impacts, volcanic eruptions, or climate change.
tossups.answer: mass extinction events [prompt on catastrophe or similar] <McMaken>

tossups.question: This man once said, “You cannot fight against the future. Time is on our side” in a speech concerning a bill that failed to pass shortly afterwards. His education minister, William Forster, worked to set up school boards and secret ballot voting within the government of this man’s nation. This man reformed his nation’s army through the Cardwell Reforms and wrote a work called (*) “Question of the East,” as part of his Midlothian Campaign, in which he criticized his government’s incompetence. This man notably worked with Charles Parnell to attempt to pass Irish home rule legislation, but ultimately failed. For 10 points, name this Liberal British Prime Minister who was a rival of Benjamin Disraeli.

A break-up letter from Little Rock, Arkansas posed as an anti-campaign for this entity in 2017. An optional preference for campaigns for this entity is direct flights to Seattle. Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that major landmarks around New York City would be illuminated with a trademark (*) orange color in homage to their candidacy for this entity. (*) Toronto was the only international candidate city to become a finalist for this entity. For 10 points, Los Angeles was the only West-Coast candidate out of twenty finalist cities for what entity, for which CEO Jeff Bezos announced a public international search in September 2017?
tossups.answer: HQ2 [or Amazon’s Second Headquarters or other obvious equivalents] <Halza>

tossups.question: The movement “Little Ugly Girl, Empress of the Pagodas” from Ravel’s Mother Goose suite heavily features the D-sharp version of this scale. Though not the octatonic scale, Bartók employed this scale in his compositions in an attempt to imitate old Magyar folk melodies he had found with Kodály [koh-dai]. (*) Antonín Dvořák [du-VOR-jhock] used this scale throughout his American Quartet and for the theme of the Largo section of his New World Symphony. The first two phrases of Stephen Foster’s “Oh! Susanna” use the major form of this scale. For 10 points, name this scale common in music from China, folk music, and children’s song, which can be played using just the black keys of a piano.
tossups.answer: pentatonic scale [prompt on scales with five notes] <McMaken>

tossups.question: The title character in this novel receives her coveted jacket after her attempts to return twenty dollars are rebuffed. One important conversation in this novel takes place over asparagus and sirloin, where a character persuades the title character to move in with him. This novel ends with a man using a (*) gas jet to commit suicide. The protagonist of this work also uses the last name Wheeler while married, and as her career improves, her husband, George Hurstwood, descends into poverty and gambling. This novel’s protagonist, an aspiring actress, meets Charles Drouet on a train to Chicago. For 10 points, name this novel by Theodore Dreiser about the titular girl from rural Wisconsin.

Two subsets of these structures are the c-type and the o-type, the latter of which “awaits the decision” of “the oracle” during its operation. Another type of these structures always executes the maximum number of steps and is called a “busy beaver.” Rice’s Theorem implies that the (*) halting problem is undecidable for these devices, meaning that this device cannot determine whether a program will terminate or run infinitely. These devices have a head for reading and writing on an infinitely long tape, which can be used to run any algorithm and computation as determined in a thesis co-named for Alonzo Church. For 10 points, name these theoretical computational devices named for a British computer scientist.

Edward Gibbon described the winner of this battle to be the “savior of Christendom.” Odo of Aquitaine had achieved a minor surprise victory at Toulouse prior to this battle; however, much of that territory was lost to commander Abdul al-Rahman, who would later die in this battle. The victors of this battle remarkably won (*) without a cavalry. The victorious commander at this battle would famously receive the nickname “The Hammer” for a so-called divine outcome against a far larger Umayyad army. For 10 points, name this 732 battle in modern-day France won by Frankish king Charles Martel.
tossups.answer: Battle of Tours [or Battle of Poitiers or Battle of the Palace of the Martyrs] <Halza>

tossups.question: At the point when the Sackur-Tetrode equation begins to break down, this medium begins to behave into a quantized manner and can take on a Boltzmann form when the constant phi is proportional to capital T to the three-halfs. This medium exists over a wide range of pressures when the temperature reaches the Boyle temperature, and the speed of sound in this medium is given by the square root of (*) gamma R T over M. The internal energy of this medium satisfies Joule’s Law, and an equation of state governing the thermodynamic properties of this medium can be derived from a set of laws by Avogadro, Charles, and Boyle. For 10 points, name this medium that satisfies P V equals n R T and consists of point particles undergoing perfectly elastic collisions.

The text Rhetorica ad Herennium outlines the method of loci, which relates to the enhancement of this concept. An experiment conducted by Elizabeth Loftus found that this concept is affected by differences in word choice, such as the words “collided” and “smashed” in describing a car crash. The decay of this phenomenon over time can be modeled with the (*) Ebbinghaus curve, and priming is cited as evidence for the existence of the implicit type of this process. The Atkinson-Shiffrin model introduced the idea of the “working” type of this concept, which George Miller proposed had a capacity of “seven plus or minus two.” For 10 points, name this phenomenon that is impaired in amnesiacs and includes types such as short-term and long-term.

In one story titled “The Question of” this language, a washerwoman falls in love with the teacher Monsieur Piquedent [pick-DAHNT], who makes his students use this language. In a work of twenty books in this language called Attic Nights, its author jotted down unusual anecdotes he heard in conversations, like the fable of Androcles, and in a poem in this language addressed to (*) Lesbia, the speaker says, “I hate and I love.” Another work in this language explains why mulberries are purple in the story of Pyramus and Thisbē, and yet another work in this language tells of a young man who accidentally changes into a donkey. For 10 points, name this language of such works as The Golden Ass, Metamorphoses, and the Aeneid, with authors like Catullus, Ovid, and Cicero.

The Roche Limit describes the distance at which these structures will form from surrounding particulates. Thirteen of these structures have been identified since 1977 in association with Uranus. Rhea was the first moon in our solar system speculated to have these structures, although other imaging suggested magnetism interfered with imaging. (*) Tidal deceleration leads scientists to believe that Phobos will break up in the next fifty million years and become Mars’ first one of these structures. For 10 points, name these disc-shaped structures that are most prominently located around Saturn.

bonuses.leadin: This novel features cameos from artists such as Hells Angels and The Grateful Dead. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Tom Wolfe novel that follows Ken Kesey and the Merry Pranksters and their cross-country adventures as well as their experiences experimenting with LSD.
The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test is one of the most famous works of this literary style, unconventional for its subjective perspective and writers’ immersion in their story matter.
Wolfe also wrote this controversial 1989 essay featured in Harper’s Magazine in which he criticized contemporary American novels for retreating from realism.

bonuses.leadin: The deuterocanonical book of Tobit gives the only mention in the Bible of this archangel. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this archangel who in that book travels with Tobias to help him marry a demon-filled woman and to heal his father’s blindness with a fish’s gallbladder after birds have pooped on them.

Two other books included in the Catholic deuterocanon but rejected by Protestants are titled after this group of Jewish rebels from the second century B.C.E. The second of those books recounts how Judas restored the temple, an event commemorated during Hanukkah.

Other portions of the deuterocanon include a passage in the book of Daniel about this type of animal, which is revered by the Babylonians but bursts open and dies after Daniel feeds it a cake made from pitch, fat, and hair.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the 2017 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, for 10 points each:
parts: The prize was awarded to Dubochet, Frank, and Henderson for their pioneering work in the cryo-electron form of this field that probes small resolution ranges. Other types of this field include “scanning electron” and “optical.”

Dubochet’s contribution to the field involved performing this process on water. In general, this process transforms a substance into a non-crystalline amorphous glass, so that if water is cooled rapidly enough, biomolecules will not be damaged by crystal formation.

Cryo-electron microscopy made possible the three-dimensional surface mapping of this virus, which led to the discovery of an E glycoprotein distinct from other flaviviruses, a discovery which may help prevent outbreaks of this virus like the one that began in 2015 in Brazil.

bonuses.leadin: The plaintiff in this court case was previously charged with being involved in the “California Gold” numbers operation. For 10 points each:
answers: Boyd v. United States [or Boyd v. U.S.] <Jin>
parts: Name this 1961 U.S. Supreme Court case in which a woman from Cleveland claimed she could not be prosecuted for the seizure of pornographic material found in her house during a search for gambling paraphernalia.
Mapp v. Ohio established the exclusionary rule, which prevents evidence obtained without a warrant from being used in court. This legal metaphor is used to describe such illegally-obtained evidence.

The decision in Mapp v. Ohio was based on this earlier 1886 U.S. Supreme Court case in which a government search of a company’s invoice papers was referred to by the court as “unreasonable search and seizure.”

bonuses.leadin: The infinite continued fraction “one plus one over quantity one plus one over quantity one, and so forth, yields this number. For 10 points each:
answers: golden ratio [or divine proportion or medial section; prompt on an approximation like 1.618]
parts: Identify this constant, symbolized lowercase phi, which is equal to its reciprocal plus one.

Because it is the root of the polynomial x2-x-1 [x-squared minus x minus one], the golden ratio is this type of number, which differs from transcendental numbers like pi in that it can be expressed as the root of a polynomial with non-zero, rational coefficients.

The golden ratio is also the limit of the ratio of consecutive numbers in a sequence named for the author of this work. That author, Fibonacci, did not mention the golden ratio in this work, instead spending most of the time rocking the Western world with the Hindu–Arabic numeral system and making up stories about rabbits.

bonuses.leadin: This man rose to prominence as a General during the Peninsular campaign in the Napoleonic Wars. For 10 points each:
answers: The Hundred Days [anti-prompt on War of the Seventh Coalition]
parts: Name this man who served as British prime minister twice as a Tory after the end of the Napoleonic Wars and oversaw the passage of the Catholic Relief Act of 1829 and the Reform Act of 1832.

Arthur Wellesley commanded the allied army, along with a Prussian army under Blücher, at the Battle of Waterloo during this period between Napoleon’s return from exile and the second restoration of Louis XVIII [“the eighteenth”].

During the Hundred Days, this meeting was occurring simultaneously. Its main objective was to secure a long term peace in Europe following Napoleon’s surrender in May 1814, and it was chaired by Austrian statesman Klemens von Metternich.

bonuses.leadin: Using a radioactive carbon-14 isotope as a tracer, Andrew Benson and this reaction series’ other namesake mapped carbon’s complete route through this cycle during photosynthesis. For 10 points each:
answers: RuBisCO [or ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase oxygenase, but not if they’re trying to sound smart and end up messing up part of it]
parts: Name this cycle in which ribulose bisphosphate catches carbon dioxide and makes sugar for plants.

This enzyme catalyzes the first major step of carbon fixation in the Calvin cycle. It uses ATP and NADPH to break six-carbon molecules into two equal parts, and it is the most abundant protein on Earth.

To ensure that RuBisCO is not wastefully fixing oxygen instead of carbon dioxide, this pathway is utilized by some plants to bypass the photorespiration pathway. It involves binding PEP with CO2 to produce a compound with its namesake number of carbons.

bonuses.leadin: Many Jewish individuals have written autobiographical accounts of the Holocaust. For 10 points each:
parts: This Romanian-born American Jew wrote the memoir Night to describe his experiences in Auschwitz and Buchenwald. He also wrote “The Jews of Silence.”
This girl lived in an attic with her family for two years while hiding from the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands, which she recounts in her work The Diary of a Young Girl.

This is Anne Frank’s older sister. She apparently kept a diary of her own that has never been found, and both her and Anne died of typhus a few months after being transferred out of Auschwitz to a different camp.

bonuses.leadin: A pre-Protestant Christian group named for this man prompted a series of namesake Bohemian wars that lasted from 1419 to 1433. For 10 points each:
answers: burned at the stake [or obvious equivalents] <Halza>
parts: Name this Bohemian priest, who was an advocate of realism in the Catholic Church and was a strong proponent of John Wycliffe, whose writings were first banned by Pope Innocent VII [“the seventh”].

Jan Hus [YAWN HOOSE], startled by the educational disparity of country priests in Bohemia, translated many religious texts into this language, his native tongue. Jan Hus completed much of his work before leaving university in Prague.

Having been found guilty of heresy by the Catholic Church, Jan Hus was put to death in this manner. Joan of Arc was also notably put to death in this fashion due to a conviction of heresy by repeated cross-dressing.

bonuses.leadin: Special types of this phenomenon include “ball,” “bead,” and “heat” types. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this phenomenon that occurs when the atmospheric field strength exceeds about three million volts per meter.
Lightning consists of the partially-ionized form of this state of matter which may be the most abundant state in the Universe because of its presence in stars.
Lightning is initiated by this effect when water and ice droplets interact with friction. This effect’s namesake series pairs amber with wool and glass with silk.

bonuses.leadin: Two violins bray like a donkey in the shortest movement of this work. For 10 points each:
answers: The Carnival of the Animals [or Le carnaval des animaux]
Fossils [or Fossiles; prompt on the twelfth movement]
parts: Name this zoological fantasy by Camille Saint-Saëns [ca-MEE san-SAW] that includes such movements as “Characters with Long Ears” and “The Swan.”

This movement of The Carnival of the Animals quotes the French “Twinkle Twinkle Little Star” and Rossini’s “Una voce [VOH-chay] poco fa.” The xylophone in this movement mimics another composition by Saint-Saëns, Danse Macabre.

The ninth movement, The Cuckoo in the Depths of the Woods, is scored for these two instruments. One repeats the two-note ostinato C-A-flat to mimic the call of the cuckoo, while a pair of the other instrument supplies large, soft chords.

bonuses.leadin: This bandit from Attica was killed when Theseus forced him to fit in his own bed. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man who loved to stretch people or cut off their feet to make them fit his beds.
In the underworld, this son of Elara and Zeus was stretched out over nine acres and had his liver eaten by two vultures. Hera had him try to rape Leto in revenge for Zeus’ infidelity.
Like Tityus, this titan, who brought fire to mankind, was chained to a rock and had his liver eaten until he was freed by Hercules.

bonuses.leadin: This painting contains a quadrant, a globe, and a lute with a broken string. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this double portrait by Hans Holbein the Younger in which Jean de Dinteville and Georges de Selve stand next to shelves of various scientific, musical, and religious items.

This object appears distorted at the bottom of The Ambassadors, rendered in anamorphic perspective. This object’s inclusion in the painting may be for the thematic representation of mortality and death.
Another reminder of mortality in the painting is this object, which appears in the upper left on the wall and is partially obscured by the green curtain covering the rest of the upper background.

bonuses.leadin: Armies throughout history have attempted to use animals as weapons. For 10 points each:
parts: Hannibal, noted for his use of war elephants, was defeated at this battle by Scipio Africanus, who brilliantly defeated the formidable elephants by allowing them to charge past his ranks and remove them from battle.

These small animals were used extensively in World War I to communicate between army divisions. One of these animals, a blue check hen named Cher Ami, delivered a message saving the “Lost Battalion” despite being shot in the wing.

The Russian military trained dogs strapped with explosives to run under enemy tanks in this war. Although their success is uncertain, twelve German tanks were disabled by dog-chartered explosives at the Battle of Kursk in this war.

bonuses.leadin: The title character in this opera sings the aria Ritorna vincitor to profess her struggle between love for her father, country, and Radamès. For 10 points each:
answers: being buried alive in the temple vault <McMaken>
parts: Name this Italian opera by Giuseppe Verdi in which Amneris vies with the title princess for the love of Radamès.
Aida and her father Amonasro are from this country, having been captured and enslaved by the Egyptians.
For Radamès’ treason, he is sentenced to die in this manner. He soon finds that Aida has also sneaked her way to die in this manner as well.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about some cities in Nigeria, for 10 points each:
parts: This coastal port city is the most populated city in Nigeria and was the capital prior to the transition to Abuja in 1991. Separated into two portions, the “Island” and the “Mainland,” this city gets its name from the Portuguese word for “lakes.”

Maiduguri, the capital of Borno State, is situated near the Firki swamps of this natural feature. The terrorist group Boko Haram is prolific in the undeveloped northeastern Nigerian landscape around this receding endorheic lake.

This capital and largest city of Rivers State is Nigeria’s primary exporter of petroleum. Located in the Niger Delta, this southeastern city is located on the Bonny River prior to its drainage in the Gulf of Guinea.

bonuses.leadin: Michel Foucault referenced this work in his The Order of Things, commenting on the author’s system of Chinese taxonomy he made up in writing this work. For 10 points each:
answers: Dr. Yu Tsun [accept either underlined portion]
Jorge Francisco Isidoro Luis Borges Acevedo <Jin>
parts: For 10 points, name this essay that critiques the work of an English philosopher, An Essay towards a Real Character and a Philosophical Language, which proposes a system for a universal language.

The same author who wrote “The Analytical Language of John Wilkins” also wrote about this character, a German spy who conveys the reveals the location of an artillery park by murdering a man who shared the location’s name.

This Argentine author wrote both “The Analytical Language of John Wilkins” and The Garden of Forking Paths, in which Dr. Yu Tsun appears. He is also known for other works such as “The Aleph” and “The Library of Babel.”

bonuses.leadin: Numerous resignations have plagued the current administration under President Trump. For 10 points each:
parts: This former White House Press Secretary was often satirized on Saturday Night Live by an emphatic Melissa McCarthy and was noted for his habit of chewing and swallowing large quantities of gum.
Name this former member of President Trump’s Cabinet, who resigned from his post as Secretary of Health and Human Services due to inappropriate use of government aircrafts and charters.
This former White House Director of Communications and confidante to President Trump resigned suddenly on March 1st, 2018. She succeeded Anthony Scaramucci in her post.

bonuses.leadin: This man wrote under pseudonyms like Captain Scipio and Johannes de Silentio to separate himself from his ideas. For 10 points each:
answers: Fear and Trembling [or Frygt og Bæven]
parts: Name this Danish philosopher who wrote the works The Concept of Anxiety and Either/Or.

Kierkegaard contrasts the Knight of Faith with the Knight of Infinite Resignation in this work which discusses Abraham’s sacrifice of his son Isaac and asks, “Is there a teleological suspension of the ethical?” This work is named for a line from Philippians 2:12.

Kierkegaard’s three stages on life’s way are the aesthetic, the ethical, and this third stage which he considered to be the highest plane of existence. In this stage, one is ruled by “total faith in God.”

bonuses.leadin: This collection includes a poem in which the speaker concludes that he is “a happy fly” regardless of whether he lives or dies. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poetry collection that also includes a poem about a speaker who waters his wrath “night and morning with [his] tears,” eventually murdering his foe at the end of the poem.
This British poet wrote a two-part poem about a boy who works as a chimney sweeper. He split those parts among his collections Songs of Innocence and Songs of Experience.

Blake wrote this poem that is paired with an illustration of the title plant represented as a human. This poem is included as the 12th section of Benjamin Britten’s song cycle Songs and Proverbs of William Blake.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Falklands War, for 10 points each:
answers: the United Kingdom and Argentina [or Great Britain and Argentina]
parts: The Falklands War was fought between these two nations.
This British prime minister was in office in 1982 during the Falklands War. This longest-serving prime minister of the 20th century was also known as the “Iron Lady.”

The surrender of the Argentinian forces occurred at this capital of the Falkland Islands. The name of this city is shared with the surname of an explorer who was famously quoted as saying “Dr. Livingstone, I presume?”
